text: And my name is Jono Alcaro. I'm the at-large member of the Albemarle County School Board. I will state for the record, and the minutes of this meeting should so reflect, that the meeting is being held electronically pursuant to Virginia state law and Albemarle County ordinance.  because the COVID-19 pandemic makes it impracticable and unsafe to assemble a quorum physically in a single location. The meeting is being streamed live on the Albemarle County Public Schools website and public comment may be offered through the Zoom waiting feature in accordance with the school board's protocol or by written submission.  I'd also like to say for anybody listening in who is looking at an older agenda, item 2.2 has been moved to the second meeting, which would be a week from tomorrow, of the school board retreat. Ms. Schmidt is going to be meeting with some of the people involved in that particular issue.  We would like to incorporate that into the presentation to the board. And I just want to read one statement that I think is highly important. Tomorrow, June 19, is the oldest national celebration of the ending of slavery in the United States. On that day in 1865,  A general order was read to the people of the last slave-holding state in the Union in Texas, which said in part, all slaves are now free. The order proclaimed that this action involved the absolute equality of rights between former slaves and their owners. History has sadly not agreed.  Over the past 155 years, slavery's disgraceful legacy separated those rights, consistently destroying lives and families and causing incalculable damage to our nation. It is still doing those awful things today. Public schools were not established for such purposes. They were established to be the place where all children  would receive equal opportunities to be safe and cared for and to learn and develop at their highest potential. We are not yet such a place. Earlier this week, Governor Northam said, slavery is not just the history of our black communities, this is everyone's shared history.  Our anti-racism policy promises, quote, we are committed to establishing and sustaining an equitable community that achieves the school division's equity mission to end the predictive value of race and ensure the success of each individual student and staff member. To appropriately embrace this unity of purpose,  It is imperative that our school division join the state and our country, and our county, rather, in designating June 19, Juneteenth, as a time of personal reflection and renewed commitment to racial justice and equality for all. A day that stands in tall fulfillment of the four values of our school division, to serve all of our students all of the time,  to partner with members of our community, to respect all, and to achieve excellence in our relationships with all. It is appropriate to celebrate that which is the true place of public education in our communities and in our nation. And so I call upon my colleagues on the board to approve effective immediately that every June 19 will be a day of honor.  a day of personal reflection and renewed commitment to equal opportunity and justice for all, and be set aside as a paid holiday for all school division employees. May I have a motion, if someone is comfortable, to approve this?  I move that we approve the statement, placing the Juneteenth statement, placing our county in line with county and state guidelines as outlined by Governor Northam.

text: Good afternoon. My name is Rosalyn Schmidt. I'm the Chief Operating Officer. I believe this is our third or fourth COVID update meeting. In the past, we've done a round robin of updates from various staff members. But this afternoon, we just have three brief topics that we will spend the, excuse me, we have just three brief topics to touch upon, but we'll spend the bulk of the agenda on the work of the Return to School Task Force.  First, I just have a brief update on our student meal service. Our student meal service is continuing to operate as we transitioned into the summer.  Sorry, I want to make sure I was on the right side there. Most certainly, as we transitioned into the summer, we did make some slight location and time changes. Most notably, at smaller stops, we were able to consolidate and reduce to only three days a week. This was more efficient on our side, but hopefully more convenient for families as well. Students received two days worth of meals at a time, so they are still receiving the same amount of food.  We have publicly communicated that we are operating through June 30th, but we are finalizing details to continue throughout the summer, and we'll communicate times and locations once they are set. Just this week, we've learned that the DOE and the USDA have continued all previous waivers, which is great news and will allow us to serve all schools throughout the summer. I will now hand it over to Dr. Kaiser, who will review how we are bringing staff back to our buildings.

text: Good afternoon board, this is Claire Kaiser assistant superintendent. I'm very pleased to share with you that we have begun to return the work we have begun the return to work process for our 11 and 12 month staff members.  We are doing this through a phased approach to allow our employees to return to work in a safe manner as we prepare for the opening of school. Through each of these phases, we continue to follow the guidelines of the CDC, the Virginia Department of Health, as well as advisement from Governor Northam and our state superintendent.  Summer phase one began this past Monday. During this phase, our employees may continue to telecommute as their work allows. For employees whose work does not allow for them to telecommute, we have welcomed them back physically to their workspace. Most of the employees who have reported back to work at their physical sites are in the support services. The leadership of each of our support departments has developed protocols for their employees to return to work.  These include, but are not limited to, the adjustment of schedules and workspaces to allow for physical distancing, use of masks when physical distancing is not allowable, and daily employee health self-screenings. They also have done orientations to ensure that employees are aware of the expectations and changes to the protocols from what they typically have done in their workspace. With the start of summer phase one, the need for essential pay is eliminated per our building closure policy.  We will begin summer phase two on July 6th. The goal of this phase is to transition all of our 12-month employees back to their work sites. While this will begin July 6th, the transition will be completed with all 12-month employees physically back at work 15 days, 15 work days that is, prior to the teachers returning. Beginning July 6th, phones will again be answered at the school or department rather than using a centralized phone line as we have done through the closure.  Our buildings will be open for visitors by appointment and with direction from the governor and state superintendent. There will be limited on-site student experiences for both learning and athletics. Principals and department leaders are working on protocols to safely bring their employees back to work in this phase. The third phase will be encompassed in the return to school plan that we will be sharing later in this meeting.  We recognize that there is considerable concern by our employees regarding the safe return to work. Through our current leave options and the Families First Coronavirus Relief Act, which allows for emergency sick leave and emergency family medical leave for qualified employees, we will work with our employees who feel that they are not able to return to work. We recognize that this is a delicate balance between the needs of the employees and the ability for us to return to the normal operations of the school division.  And with that, I will turn it over to Ms. Collins.

text: Good afternoon, members of the school board. I am Rick Verhoevec, principal of Monticello High School. I had the pleasure of working with Rosalind Schmidt on healthy environments. Our team consisted of 16 fellow administrators,  athletic directors, nurses, and teachers. We reviewed information shared by Governor Northam, the Virginia Department of Education, and the Center for Disease Control. There were many topics that we discussed early on, but we defined our purpose to develop practices and protocols that were necessary in reopening schools in a safe manner for all of our stakeholders.  We narrowed our focus to four areas, cleaning, building and grounds, transportation, and our response to confirmed cases of COVID-19. So cleaning and disinfecting of learning spaces and materials before, during, and after all uses. We will follow the guidelines from the Center for Disease Control and Health Organizations to operate our buildings  to reduce the exposure of COVID-19. We will maximize the spaces that we have in our building, utilizing our buildings to minimize contact and the sharing of equipment. Transportation, which is one of the highest priorities for us returning to school. Establishing protocols for cleaning our buses before and after use. Using personal protection equipment.  for students and staff, maintaining social distancing, designing routes to meet the needs of all of our students and families, and communication on the use of transportation, the expectations, and our schedules. Finally, making sure that we have protocols that will be in place in response to confirmed cases of COVID-19 in our buildings. Thank you.

text: Thank you, Ms. Collins and good afternoon members of the board. My name is Craig Domer and I'm the principal at Hollywood Elementary School. Dr. Kaiser and I were also privileged to work with 14 talented educators on the healthy staff section of the document.  As we began work, we were often guided by the essential question of what will it take to have employees feel as safe and confident as possible in returning to work. After much brainstorming, we landed on a statement of purpose that you see before you, and three key areas of physical safety, mental health, and attendance and leave. Professional development was an area that ran throughout the entire document, and the steering committee decided to consolidate it under healthy staff, giving us our four key areas.  Each work group worked to come up with guidelines for strategies in those areas that encompass the scope of action that will be necessary to achieve our purpose. Physical safety, while having some overlap with healthy environments, our group focused on creating guidelines for creating staff health screening upon entrance, physical distancing measures, consideration for PPE for different staff members based on contact with others, and how staff should interact with visitors in the building.  Mental health was a key component and concern for our group as we acknowledge the added stress that teaching and working in the pandemic will have. The work group worked with human resources on both the schools and the local government side to focus on making sure that we were promoting programs currently in place, adding additional support for administrators and supervisors to be able to guide staff to those resources and creating a peer-to-peer program for providing support.  As I said previously, professional development was the theme throughout, and we'll need to take steps to make sure that all employees are knowledgeable and have the skills to manage both the changes in practice for health and safety, as well as making sure that we're prepared to meet the instructional needs of our students in different environments. Attendance and leave is a technical area for our group, as we need to respond to employees with a varied set of circumstances.  The workgroup was able to create guidelines that we feel are based both around the types of leave available and mandated by federal regulations, and an overall sense that as an organization, we will work with employees to accommodate their situations for their safety while meeting the needs of our students. There's obviously a lot of work still to be done, but we feel that our workgroup has captured the scope and guidelines necessary to create and implement practices that will ensure a healthy, safe, and productive return to work for our staff. Thank you.
speaker: craigdomme

text: Thank you, Mr. Domer. Healthy Students was co-chaired by Ms. Johnson and Mr. Thomas. I think Ms. Johnson will bring us information in this focus area.

text: Yes, good afternoon, school board and community members. My name is Ashby Johnson and I'm the principal at Jack Jewett Middle School. I worked with our director of secondary education, Jay Thomas, and a team of about 20 other educators on the Healthy Students group.  Our group focused on four main areas in order to prioritize the physical and mental health of all of our students. Those four areas were physical health and safety, mental health and well-being, scheduling options, and athletics, field trips, and extracurriculars. We had four main guiding questions that drove our committee work. I will highlight some key areas from each question for you all today.  Under physical health and safety, we will both coordinate and partner with families to educate them on the symptoms of COVID-19 and the procedures for what to do if they think their child is ill or has become exposed to the virus. We will survey families to determine the current health of students and needs of the family before we reopen. We will work to develop safety protocols that align to the public health guidelines.  Schools will repurpose non-traditional learning spaces such as cafeterias and gyms to comply with social distancing guidelines. We will also minimize the amount of movement in between classes at especially the elementary school level. In order to identify and support the mental health and wellbeing of all of our students, we will collaborate with our school counselors and community service providers to develop protocols and procedures to support our students. Again, this will include a survey to families to determine needs  We will develop and strengthen our current programs, such as Check and Connect, Freshman Seminar, Responsive Classroom, and Developmental Designs. We will establish a community outreach team to partner with Region 10, DSS, and other community agencies. Next, we focused on scheduling options that would support multiple learning environments. This was an extremely challenging area to think through. We determined that scheduling should be equitable and flexible.  and might vary based on elementary and secondary levels and even specific buildings for the needs of all students. And although you won't see specific plans outlined, we felt strongly that we needed to prioritize in-person learning for our youngest students, English language learners and students with disabilities. In order to do this, we will have to communicate and coordinate with transportation services to ensure that we can meet the transportation needs of any potential plan that we put in place.

text: Yes, I am. Good afternoon, everyone. I am Woodette Crummey, Principal of Crozet Elementary. I work with Michelle Kastner, Director of Elementary Schools. Our first task was to reflect and brainstorm together what worked for our students during the COVID-19 and what did not work. One of the key things we heard was how critical it was for teachers  to stay connected with their students to help them navigate learning through this new environment. We developed five focus areas that you see before you that include design principles and practices to serve as guidelines to ensure our support of student learning.  Our commitment is that our shared philosophical tenets of high quality teaching and learning will be present in any environment, which leads to our healthy learning guiding questions to address those five focus areas. text: Good afternoon, board members. I'm Pat McLaughlin, chief of strategic planning. And before I dive into the calendar, I just want to respond once more to Ms. Lee's request I just heard from Jennifer Butler and COVID-19 results will be posted on our survey results page this afternoon. So I'll send those to you as well, but any members of the public can access those then. So onto the calendar. As part of our return to school plan, Albemarle County Public Schools solicited feedback from the community about changing the start date  of school to be later in the year. As you can see here, our response rate was very robust. Usually when we do a calendar survey, we're lucky to get about 11 or 1,200 respondents. We had close to 5,000 this time. Most of those were parents and staff members and students, but also had about 95 community members. And that's in the space of less than a week. We opened up the survey on June the 11th and just closed it yesterday.  And so I'll share the results of that survey with you tonight. I want to just take a minute, too, to thank Mr. Page for encouraging us last week to look for ways to engage stakeholders without Internet access in the survey. With a very quick turnaround time, the technology and communications teams enacted a phone survey feature in Blackboard Connect that we hadn't used before.  This allowed us to send a phone survey in both English and Spanish to 568 homes without internet access. 101 of those families opted to participate. And I think this is just a wonderful example of a practice that helps to close the opportunity gap for families in the school division.  So onto the results. A majority of respondents believe that the later start date would be beneficial to students. That was the first question that we asked them. You can see that 51.8% responded with either a four or a five in terms of the benefits of a later start date.  Close to 30% of respondents believed a change would not be beneficial to students. And this had a weighted score of 3.36 out of five, which indicates to us the general consensus is to shift the start date to a later date in the school calendar. Next, we asked folks to what degree they were satisfied with each of our two drafts.  For the start date of September 2nd, respondents were asked to rate their level of satisfaction. This one had a weighted score below three, indicating that respondents would not be satisfied with this draft calendar. The plurality of the responses was a neutral response, indicating they were neither satisfied or dissatisfied, which could show a little bit of ambivalence toward this particular version of the calendar.  The second calendar option with a September 8th start date was rated more favorably with a weighted score of 3.45 indicating general satisfaction. The plurality of responses selected very satisfied with this draft and about 28.5% of responses selected a level of dissatisfaction with this draft of the calendar.  We had about 250 pages of comments to go through. And so with the survey ending yesterday, we have not been able to disaggregate those in a way that would be meaningful to the board yet. But as soon as we have that, we can pass that information along to you. And so we just wanted to talk about next steps. That our hope, as you saw in Ms. Collins' presentation earlier, is that we can have a board vote on the calendar at the June 26th as part two of the board retreat. And really there you've got three options to stick with the original calendar,  to move to the September 2nd start date in the calendar or to move to the September 8th start date in the calendar. And so that's our hope that on the 26th, we can finalize that and have one more item checked off the list as we begin to implement our return to school plan. So those are the results of the survey. They will be, I believe they are already published on our survey results page as well for the public to see. And I'll be happy to take any questions that you have.

text: Okay, thank you. I'm Jamie Gellner, the division program evaluator filling in on behalf of Nick King, our student services officer. And last week you asked us to put together a program review in our school resource officer program. So here are our ideas moving forward with a quick turnaround. As you may know, our MOU, formerly called the Joint Protocol between ACPS and ACPD, states that the scope of the SRO responsibilities include these things, to promote a positive and supportive school climate, as well as safe and secure environments, to collaborate with the schools and to reduce and prevent crime,  to minimize student involvement with the criminal justice systems. The MOU points out that the school resource officer, therefore, has many roles in our schools, including law enforcement officer, law-related educator, informal mentor and role model, resource for criminal charges and cases, and a resource for information on gang activity and participation.  Our program has five officers, one at Albemarle High School and one to cover the rest of the feeder pattern, one at Monticello and one to cover the rest of the feeder pattern, and one in the Western feeder pattern. The SROs report to their own chain of command and Nick is our direct contact for ACPS. We will pull together several pieces of data for the board. The Code of Virginia requires school divisions to submit data to VDOE  on incidents of disciplined crime and violence. Current reports contain selected comparisons to prior years. And this data are used also to complete federal reports required by the Gun Free Schools Act and the Individual with Disabilities Education Act. This report requires an annual reporting of the number of students suspended or expelled statewide for possessing or bringing firearms on school property.  We'll also look at our state and local climate surveys, which have statements about how safe students feel at school, although they don't specifically ask about school resource officers. We will review the ACPS threat assessment reports from last year. We will send a survey out to students grades six through 12 tomorrow, asking them about their level of comfort with school resource officers and their experiences.  We have already asked for principal input about their experience with school resource officers, and we will provide a research brief from Dewey Cornell, who is a professor in the career school at UVA, who is known for his research on youth violence and school security. We've also reached out to EAB for a quick turnaround research request on program outcomes of school resource officer programs, and have various other studies, articles, and applicable ACPS policies for your review.  So today we have presented the items for the program review. June 26, we will present the complete information for the board's review.
